newsitem.title: USA: Exotic bird expert sentenced for parrot smuggling.
newsitem.headline: Exotic bird expert sentenced for parrot smuggling.

text.p: A Chicago expert on exotic birds has been sentenced to 82 months in jail for heading an international parrot smuggling ring, the U.S. Department of Justice said on Tuesday.

Tony Silva was sentenced in federal court on Monday to the longest U.S. prison term ever handed out for bird smuggling, the department said in a statement. Silva, 36, is an internationally prominent writer and lecturer on the plight of endangered parrots in the wild.
He pleaded guilty on Jan. 30 to a broad conspiracy involving his mother and others to smuggle into the United States hundreds of rare birds trapped in the wild in South America, the department said.

Among the birds, valued at more than $1.3 million altogether, were dozens of hyacinth macaws, an endangered species of which no more than 5,000 are estimated to survive in Brazil, the department said.

"It is disgraceful that a person of Mr. Silva's stature in the avicultural community has engaged in activity that proved directly fatal to many hyacinth macaws and other highly endangered species," James Burns, the U.S. attorney for the Northern District of Illinois, said.
Silva also pleaded guilty to filing a false income tax return in connection with the sale of birds.
